newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Buy-on-dip seen prevailing in US T-bonds.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Buy-on-dip seen prevailing in US T-bonds.

text.p: Buying-on-dip strategies look to be the flavor of the month in the bullish but overbought U.S. Treasury bond futures market, technical analysts said.
With bond prices still in a three-month-old rising channel, the market is likely to stay well supported on pullbacks, they said.
"I'd certainly be willing to buy during any weakness that develops in the next week or two," said Jim Bohan, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Basically, he noted, the market has been in a consolidative range-trade in the past several days.

Early Tuesday, September T-bonds slipped to a low of 113-7/32, down 23/32 on the day, on stronger than expected June U.S. retail sales data. Then they quickly reversed and recouped most of the losses by late morning trade.
"It's looking much better on the reaction bounce off the lows," said Matthew Crosson, director of fixed income at Pegasus Econometrics Group.

He said a trendline on the hourly charts, coming in in the 113-26/32 to 113-28/32 area, was hindering a further bounce back for now but added that he anticipated the market to edge higher in the near term.
He added that the daily stochastic and other short-term oscillators, which had been looking toppish for some time now, had yet to come down out of the overbought territory.
Still, analysts agreed that the lower end of the rising channel supported September T-bonds in the low-112 area, while the mid-114 to mid-115 area was strong channel resistance.
Bohan added that that resistance area coincided with the December 1996 highs.
"The combination of the fact that you're bumping into the upper end of the trend channel and the '96 resistance, I think, has produced a consolidation phase," he said.
Crosson pointed out that commodity prices, which had fallen with strong negative correlation to rising bond prices in recent months, appeared to be basing now.
That, he said, might also dampen bonds' advances somewhat in the near term.
"This very well could go on for a while longer," Bohan said, predicting a few more weeks of consolidation.

"Ultimately, though, I expect the market to go higher, maybe significantly higher, because the background is so positive," he said. "If there are going to be surprises, I would think they would be on the upside."
